{{Infobox company | name = Doppler Labs | logo = Doppler Labs logo.png | image = Here One earbuds in white charging case.jpg | image_caption = The Here One earbuds by Doppler Labs charging in their carrying case. | type = [[Private company|Private]] | industry = Technology | founded = November 2013 in [[New York City]], [[United States]] | founders = [[Noah Kraft]] ([[CEO]]) & [[Fritz Lanman]] ([[Chairman]]) | defunct = December 1, 2017 | hq_location_city = [[San Francisco]] | hq_location_country = [[United States]] | area_served = Worldwide | num_employees = 75 | num_employees_year = <!-- Year of num_employees data (if known) --> | parent = | website = {{URL|http://hereplus.me}} }}
'''Doppler Labs''' was a [[San Francisco]]-based [[Sound recording and reproduction|audio technology]] company. Founded in 2013 in [[New York City]], the company's mission was to make computing more immersive and human.<ref name="crunchbase">{{cite web|title=Doppler Labs {{!}} Crunchbase|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/doppler-labs|website=Crunchbase|accessdate=6 November 2017|language=en}}</ref> The company designed and manufactured in-ear computing technology, including [[earplug]]s and [[wireless]] smart [[Headphones|earbuds]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://qz.com/870552/doppler-labs-wants-to-put-two-extra-brains-in-your-ears/|title=Doppler Labs wants to put two extra brains in your ears|last=Gershgorn|first=Dave|work=Quartz|access-date=2017-05-13|language=en-US}}</ref>
== History == Doppler Labs was co-founded by [[Noah Kraft]] and [[Fritz Lanman]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/doppler-labs#/entity|title=Doppler Labs {{!}} crunchbase|website=www.crunchbase.com|access-date=2017-05-13}}</ref> Kraft had previously worked in the entertainment industry,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/noah-kraft/|title=Noah Kraft|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-05-13|language=en}}</ref> while Lanman was an executive at [[Microsoft]] and a prominent [[angel investor]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/03/17/classpass-ceo-fritz-lanman-payal-kadakia/|title=Fritz Lanman takes CEO role at ClassPass as founder Payal Kadakia steps in as Chairman|last=Crook|first=Jordan|date=|website=TechCrunch|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-05-13|quote=Lanman is a former Microsofter who has gone on to angel invest in companies like Wish, Pinterest, and Square. He’s also the Chairman of the Board on two of his other portfolio companies, Verst and Doppler Labs.}}</ref>
In July 2015, Doppler raised $17 million in [[Series B funding]] bringing the company's total funding to over $50 million.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/aarontilley/2015/07/07/audio-wearables-startup-doppler-labs-raises-17-million/|title=Audio Wearable Startup Doppler Labs Raises $17 Million|last=Tilley|first=Aaron|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-05-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/07/07/doppler-labs-lands-17-million-in-series-b/|title=Doppler Labs Lands $17 Million In Series B|last=Crook|first=Jordan|website=TechCrunch|access-date=2017-05-13}}</ref> The round was led by [[The Chernin Group]], Wildcat Capital Management, and Acequia Capital and included luminary investors like [[Henry Kravis]], [[David Geffen]], [[Blake Krikorian]], [[Dan Gilbert]], [[David Bonderman]] and [[Barry Sternlicht]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2016/07/19/doppler-labs-raises-24-million-led-by-the-chernin-group-for-wireless-listening-system/|title=Doppler Labs raises $24 million led by The Chernin Group for wireless listening system|date=2016-07-19|website=VentureBeat|access-date=2017-05-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/07/19/doppler-labs-raises-another-24m-to-put-a-computer-in-your-ear/|title=Doppler Labs raises another $24m to put a computer in your ear|last=Crook|first=Jordan|website=TechCrunch|access-date=2017-05-13}}</ref>
Doppler Labs first product was [[DUBS Acoustic Filters]], high-tech ear plugs designed that use a proprietary 17-piece physical acoustic filter system to reduce the sound pressure at different frequencies while maintaining acoustical fidelity.<ref name="Gizmodo '14">{{cite web|last1=Aguilar|first1=Mario|title=Dubs Earplugs Don't Look Terrible So You Might Actually Wear Them|url=https://gizmodo.com/dubs-earplugs-dont-look-terrible-so-you-might-actually-1638017710|website=Gizmodo|accessdate=1 December 2017}}</ref><ref name="TechCrunch">{{cite web|last1=Crook|first1=Jordan|title=Meet Dubs, Doppler Labs’ Reinvention Of The Lowly Earplug|url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/09/23/meet-dubs-doppler-labs-reinvention-of-the-lowly-earplug/|website=TechCrunch|accessdate=1 December 2017|language=en}}</ref> In July 2016, Doppler Labs Labs launched Here Active Listening at the [[Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3059147/how-to-make-coachella-even-trippier-augmented-reality-earbuds|title=How To Make Coachella Even Trippier: Augmented Reality Earbuds|date=2016-04-22|work=Fast Company|access-date=2017-08-17|language=en-US}}</ref> and in 2017 launched its flagship product [[Here One Wireless Smart Earbuds|Here One]], a pair of wireless smart earbuds <ref name="Wired">{{cite web|last1=Pierce|first1=David|title=Doppler’s New Earbuds Are Way More Than Just Wireless Headphones|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/ones-earbuds-way-just-wireless-headphones/|website=WIRED|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref> that allow users to selectively filter ambient sound, stream music, and amplify speech. It can also be used to take phone calls and selectively filter certain sounds, such as background noise.<ref name="Business Insider">{{cite web|last1=Dunn|first1=Jeff|title=These wireless earbuds are like mini computers for your ears that are as powerful as a 2010 laptop|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/doppler-labs-here-one-wireless-earbuds-2016-6|website=Business Insider|accessdate=14 November 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref name="Forbes">{{cite web|last1=Auerbach|first1=Brad|title=Doppler Labs Launches Here One: Not Only a Volume Knob in a Loud World, a Supercomputer in Every Ear|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/bradauerbach/2016/06/28/doppler-labs-launches-here-one-not-only-a-volume-knob-in-a-loud-world-a-supercomputer-in-every-ear/#55d25d65315a|website=Forbes|accessdate=14 November 2017|language=en}}</ref> Here One has been called the world’s first in-ear computer.<ref name="business insider 2">{{cite web|last1=Dunn|first1=Jeff|title=These wireless earbuds transform the sounds around you and preview a future of in-ear computers — here's what they're like|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/doppler-labs-here-one-preview-in-ear-computers-report-2016-11/#-3|website=Business Insider|accessdate=14 November 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/2017/02/review-here-one/|title=The Here One wireless earbuds let you remix reality|last=Pierce|first=David|work=WIRED|access-date=2017-08-17|language=en-US}}</ref>
In March 2017, Doppler Labs sued [[Bose headphones|Bose]] for trademark infringement of their Here Buds trademark.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/doppler-labs-bose-lawsuit-here-one-augmented-reality-headphones-2017-3|title=$50 million startup Doppler Labs is suing Bose for allegedly tricking it into sharing its secret sound technology|work=Business Insider|access-date=2017-08-17|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.bostonherald.com/business/technology/2017/03/startup_claims_bose_stole_its_technology|title=Startup claims Bose stole its technology|access-date=2017-08-17}}</ref>
The company supported the Over-the-Counter (OTC) Hearing Aid Act of 2017,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/40423902/consumer-tech-companies-want-to-make-hearing-aids-cheaper-and-even-trendy|title=Consumer Tech Companies Want To Make Hearing Aids Cheaper—And Even Trendy|date=2017-07-07|work=Fast Company|access-date=2017-08-18|language=en-US}}</ref> which passed both [[House of Congress|houses of Congress]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.benzinga.com/pressreleases/17/08/b9874734/senate-passes-the-over-the-counter-hearing-aid-act-of-2017-bringing-aff|title=Senate Passes the Over-the-Counter Hearing Aid Act of 2017 Bringing Affordable and Accessible Hearing Health Care Closer to Reality|website=Benzinga|access-date=2017-08-18}}</ref>
On November 1, 2017, Doppler Labs announced that the company would be winding down operations, and officially closed on December 1.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/why-doppler-labs-shut-down-2017-11?op=1|title=A startup that raised $50 million to make a smarter version of Apple's AirPods has failed and shut down|last=Weinberger|first=Matt|date=1 November 2017|work=[[Business Insider]]|access-date=1 November 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> The company cited problems raising additional Series C funding as the reason for the company shutting down.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/amyfeldman/2017/11/01/once-a-unicorn-to-be-smart-earbud-startup-doppler-labs-to-shut-down/#2d12effd159a|title=Once A Unicorn-To-Be, Smart-Earbud Startup Doppler Labs To Shut Down|last=Feldman|first=Amy|date=1 November 2017|work=[[Forbes]]|access-date=1 November 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] wrote that the company unsuccessfully explored options to stay afloat including partnership, investment, and acquisition from companies such as [[Microsoft]], [[Apple Inc.|Apple]], [[Google]], [[Amazon (company)|Amazon]], and [[Facebook]]. It was preparing to launch its next product, Here Two, in 2018.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Pierce|first1=David|title=Inside the Downfall of a Wildly Ambitious Hardware Startup|url=https://www.wired.com/story/inside-the-downfall-of-doppler-labs/|website=WIRED|accessdate=20 December 2017}}</ref>
== Products == Before voice assistants or true wireless technology were prevalent, Doppler Labs envisioned that computing would move onto the body and into the ear and that voice would become a more primary interface for how humans interact with technology.<ref name="hereplus blog">{{cite web|title=Introducing Here One™: The Future Of In-Ear Computing|url=https://hereplus.me/blogs/news/introducing-here-one-the-future-of-in-ear-computing|website=Here One|accessdate=6 November 2017}}</ref> With Apple’s removal of the headphone jack,<ref name="the verge">{{cite web|title=Apple says it took 'courage' to remove the headphone jack on the iPhone 7|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/9/7/12838024/apple-iphone-7-plus-headphone-jack-removal-courage|website=The Verge|accessdate=6 November 2017}}</ref> the launch of the [[AirPods]],<ref name="apple">{{cite web|title=Apple reinvents the wireless headphone with AirPods|url=https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2016/09/apple-reinvents-the-wireless-headphones-with-airpods/|website=Apple Newsroom|accessdate=6 November 2017}}</ref> and the prevalence of [[Amazon Alexa|Alexa]],<ref name="MIT">{{cite web|last1=Anders|first1=George|title=Amazon’s Alexa is a bet that in the future we will be talking to our computers|url=https://www.technologyreview.com/s/608571/alexa-understand-me/|website=MIT Technology Review|accessdate=6 November 2017|language=en}}</ref> the smart earbud category that Doppler helped create was expected to become a $40 billion industry by 2020.<ref name="nick hunn">{{cite web|url=http://www.nickhunn.com/wp-content/uploads/downloads/2016/11/The-Market-for-Hearable-Devices-2016-2020.pdf|accessdate=6 November 2017}}</ref>
[[File:Here One Schematic Doppler Labs.jpg|thumb|right|Here One Schematic Doppler Labs]]
The company develops and distributes the [[Here One Wireless Smart Earbuds]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/doppler-announces-here-one-earbuds-2016-6|title=These new wireless earbuds not only let you play music, but also customize how the world sounds around you|work=Business Insider|access-date=2017-05-13|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2016/11/22/doppler-labs-provides-augmented-reality-listening-for-fans-of-new-york-philharmonic-new-york-mets-and-cleveland-cavaliers/|title=New York Philharmonic, Mets, Cavaliers Get Augmented Reality Listening|website=Fortune|access-date=2017-05-13}}</ref> a pair of wireless 3-in-1 earbuds that combine premium audio streaming, smart noise cancellation, and speech enhancement into a single form factor,<ref name="hereplus">{{cite web|title=Here One|url=https://hereplus.me/products/here-one#overview|website=Here One|accessdate=6 November 2017}}</ref> as well as [[DUBS Acoustic Filters]] [[High tech|high-tech]] earplug.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/doppler-labs-dubs-acoustic-filters-earplugs-2015-8|title=These high-tech earplugs will let you enjoy concerts without hurting your ears|work=Business Insider|access-date=2017-05-13|language=en}}</ref> The company previously developed and released the predecessor to Here One called Here Active Listening,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/04/26/technology/doppler-labs-earbuds/index.html|title=Doppler Labs' earbuds are like Instagram filters for sound|last=Lake|first=Maggie|date=2016-04-26|website=CNNMoney|access-date=2017-05-13}}</ref> which was originally launched on [[Kickstarter]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/dopplerlabs/here-active-listening-change-the-way-you-hear-the|title=Here Active Listening - Change The Way You Hear The World|website=Kickstarter|language=en-US|access-date=2017-05-13}}</ref>
Doppler Labs has announced and demonstrated future product features, including real-time language translation<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.inc.com/salvador-rodriguez/doppler-labs-real-time-translation.html|title=How This Startup Will Make You Ditch Your Dumb Headphones|date=2017-02-21|work=Inc.com|access-date=2017-05-13|language=en}}</ref> and its “machine hearing” system.<ref name=":0" />
== Partners == In addition to its pre-existing partnerships with the [[Tao Group]], [[Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival|Coachella]], [[Bonnaroo Music Festival|Bonnaroo]] and [[Outside Lands Music and Arts Festival|Outside Lands]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/doppler-labs-announces-partnership-with-bonnaroo-and-outside-lands-festivals-300073474.html|title=Doppler Labs Announces Partnership with Bonnaroo and Outside Lands Festivals|last=Labs|first=Doppler|website=www.prnewswire.com|language=en|access-date=2017-08-18}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/technology/la-fi-tn-dubs-earplugs-20140922-story.html|title=Dubs aims to make earplugs a 'fashion staple' by focusing on design|last=Dave|first=Paresh|date=2014-09-23|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2017-08-18|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref> in November 2016, Doppler Labs announced seven new partnerships with [[New York Philharmonic|The New York Philharmonic]], the [[Cleveland Cavaliers]], the [[Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco]], [[JetBlue]], [[Gimlet Media]], MADE Fashion and [[New York Mets|The New York Mets]] to bring Here One technology to sporting events, museums, concert halls, and other live environments.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/news/2016/11/22/here-one-earbuds-wireless-computers-your-ears/94233730/|title=Here One earbuds are wireless 'computers for your ears'|work=USA TODAY|access-date=2017-08-18|language=en}}</ref>
In December 2016, they also partnered with the [[Global Citizen Festival]] to launch #HereTogether, a movement aimed at bringing greater global awareness around efforts to prevent [[hearing loss]] and to promote innovation in hearing accessibility<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/12/13/doppler-labs-new-hearing-health-campaign-goes-live-as-congress-moves-toward-otc-hearing-aids/|title=Doppler Labs launches hearing health campaign as Congress pushes for OTC hearing aids {{!}} TechCrunch|last=Crook|first=Jordan|access-date=2017-08-18}}</ref> As part of this initiative, Doppler Labs announced its Hearing Bill of Rights in April 2017<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/why-global-accessibility-awareness-day-matters-kr-liu|title=Why Global Accessibility Awareness Day Matters|date=2017-05-18|access-date=2017-08-18|language=en}}</ref>
== Awards and recognitions == * [[Inc. (magazine)|Inc Magazine]]’s Game Changing Inventions of 2015<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.inc.com/kevin-j-ryan/best-of-inc-2015-9-game-changing-inventions.html|title=9 Game-Changing Inventions You Missed in 2015|date=2016-01-13|work=Inc.com|access-date=2017-08-18|language=en}}</ref> * [[Time (magazine)|TIME Magazine]]’s Best Inventions of 2015<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/4115398/best-inventions-2015/|title=The 25 Best Inventions of 2015|last=Staff|first=TIME|website=Time|access-date=2017-08-18}}</ref> * [[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]’s World’s Most Innovative Companies in 2016 <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/most-innovative-companies/2016/sectors/music|title=The Most Innovative Companies of 2016 by Sector: Music.|work=Fast Company|access-date=2017-05-13|language=en-US}}</ref> * [[Sxsw|SXSW]]’s Best of Show in 2016<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/brianhernandez1/2016/03/24/what-is-sxsw-music-tech-film-brands/#3410345d2bf0|title=What Has SXSW Become? Lil Wayne, Emerging Artists And Big Brands Describe The Festival's Puzzling State|last=Hernandez|first=Brian Anthony|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-08-18|language=en}}</ref> * [[Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity]] Gold for Product Design in 2016<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.adweek.com/brand-marketing/google-scores-product-design-grand-prix-cannes-jacquard-connected-jacket-172126/|title=Google Scores Product Design Grand Prix at Cannes for Jacquard 'Connected' Jacket|access-date=2017-08-18|language=en-US}}</ref> * Named among [[Forbes|Forbes Magazine’s]] Next Billion-Dollar Startups list of 2016.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/amyfeldman/2016/10/19/next-billion-dollar-startups-2016/#62fbb66c549d|title=Next Billion-Dollar Startups 2016|last=Feldman|first=Amy|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-05-13}}</ref> * [[TechCrunch]] Crunchies Hardware of the Year Runner-Up Award in 2017<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/01/05/meet-the-companies-vying-for-hardware-of-the-year-at-the-crunchies/|title=Meet the companies vying for Hardware of the Year at the Crunchies {{!}} TechCrunch|last=Crook|first=Jordan|access-date=2017-08-18}}</ref>

{{Infobox company | name = Solaris Mobile Limited | logo = [[Image:SolarisMobileLogo.jpg|200px|200px]] | type = [[Subsidiary]] | industry = [[Telecommunications]] | foundation = 2008 | location = [[Dublin]], [[Ireland]] | key_people = Matthew Child(CEO) | products = Mobile Satellite Services | homepage = [http://www.solarismobile.com/ www.solarismobile.com] }} '''EchoStar Mobile''' was set up in 2008 as Solaris Mobile, a joint venture company between [[SES S.A.|SES]] and [[Eutelsat]] Communications to develop and commercialize the first [[geostationary]] [[satellite]] systems in Europe for broadcasting video, radio and data to in-vehicle receivers and to mobile devices,<ref>{{cite press release|publisher=SES ASTRA|date=February 21, 2008|url=http://www.ses.com/4233325/news/2008/4461735|title=Steve Maine Appointed By SES ASTRA And EUTELSAT As CEO Of Joint Venture For Mobile Satellite Services |accessdate = January 26, 2012}}</ref> such as mobile phones, [[portable media player]]s and [[PDA]]s. In January 2014 all stock in Solaris Mobile was acquired by [[EchoStar Corporation]]<ref>{{cite press release|publisher=Solaris Mobile|date=January 6, 2014|url=http://www.solarismobile.com/media/press-releases/echostar_acquires_european_mobile_satellite_services_provider|title=Echostar Acquires European Mobile Satellite Services Provider |accessdate = October 28, 2014}}</ref> and in March 2015 the company was renamed EchoStar Mobile.<ref>{{cite press release|publisher=EchoStar|date=March 25, 2015|url=http://www.echostar.com/NewsEvents/PressReleases/PressRelease.aspx?prid=11363|title=Solaris Mobile is Now EchoStar Mobile |accessdate = March 27, 2015}}</ref>
The agreement to set up Solaris Mobile was reached in 2006 with the company formed in 2008. SES and Eutelsat – both successful European satellite operators, providing TV and other services from geostationary satellites to millions of cable and [[direct-to-home]] viewers – invested €130m in the venture. The services to be developed included video, radio, multimedia data, interactive services, and voice communications, with the primary aim of delivering mobile television any time, anywhere. Its headquarters is in [[Dublin]], in the [[Republic of Ireland]].
Solaris Mobile's first commercial contract was with Italian media publishing group [[Class Editori]], to launch a digital radio service in Italy. A hybrid satellite/terrestrial network will initially be deployed in Milan, in October 2011 and extended across the country in 2012. Solaris claims that the network will enable Italians to access dozens of new digital radio channels broadcasting music, news, entertainment and sports, in their original format with continuity of reception across the entire country, and that the digital audio signal will be complemented with new visual media services such as programme information and traffic data.<ref>{{cite press release|publisher=Solaris Mobile|date=July 12, 2011 |url=http://www.solarismobile.com/media/news/solaris-mobile-and-class-editori-sign-agreement-to-launch-digital-radio-service-in-italy|title=SOLARIS MOBILE AND CLASS EDITORI SIGN AGREEMENT TO LAUNCH DIGITAL RADIO SERVICE IN ITALY}}</ref>
==Applications== The EU Telecoms Commissioner, Viviane Reding, has commented, "Mobile satellite services have huge potential: they can enable Europeans to access new communication services, particularly in rural and less populated regions."<ref name="ec press">{{cite press release|publisher=European Commission |date=May 14, 2009 |url=http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=IP/09/770 |title=European Commission paves the way for European mobile satellite services}}</ref>
Solaris Mobile primarily intends to provide mobile TV and interactive services to handheld and vehicle receivers. For in-vehicle use, the mobile satellite receivers could also double as web browsers providing full Internet access, and deliver interactive services such as online reservations, emergency warnings, or toll payments.
Solaris claims the technology brings a "fully-fledged TV experience" <ref>[http://www.solarismobile.com/our-solutions/mobile-tv/ ''Broadcasting in motion'']. Solaris Mobile website. Retrieved on June 1, 2009</ref> to mobile television, unavailable with purely terrestrial systems, delivering high-quality live TV, viable at high vehicle speeds, dozens of TV channels per country, and universal coverage.
The coverage across Europe will also enable the system to be used for situations when other means of communication are not possible, such as gathering data (traffic, weather, pollution) from moving vehicles, and support for emergency and rescue services in isolated regions, under extreme conditions or when terrestrial networks have been compromised.
To avoid the requirement for mobile phones with S-band reception for the satellite services, Solaris Mobile has developed a 'Pocket Gateway' in conjunction with Finnish company Elekrobit. The Gateway is a compact S-band receiver which decodes DVB-SH transmissions from the Solaris satellite and relays them over WiFi to any compatible handset with a web browser. The Gateway is also planned to be used in vehicles with a roof-mounted antenna for S-band reception with services accessed on passengers' mobile phones. The technology was demonstrated at the GSMA Mobile World Congress in Barcelona in February 2010.<ref>{{cite press release|publisher=Solaris Mobile|date=February 10, 2010|url=http://www.solarismobile.com/media-center/press-releases/pocket-gateway-device |title=Pocket Gateway Device}}</ref>
==Technology== The Solaris Mobile services use [[DVB-SH]] technology to deliver IP based data and media content to handheld and in-vehicle terminals using a hybrid satellite/terrestrial system with satellite transmission serving the whole of Europe and beyond, and terrestrial repeaters for urban and indoor penetration.
The [[S-band]] frequencies used (2.00 GHz) are reserved for the exclusive use of satellite and terrestrial mobile services, and sit alongside the [[UMTS]] frequencies already in use across Europe for [[3G]] terrestrial mobile phone services, allowing the reuse of existing cellular towers and antennas, and the simple incorporation of Solaris services in mobile handsets.
Handsets equipped with the first DVB-SH chipsets were successfully demonstrated live at the ''Mobile World Congress'' in Barcelona in February 2008.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/pressRelease/idUS186611+06-Feb-2008+PRN20080206 Major Players of the DVB-SH Ecosystem Join Forces to Demonstrate Live Mobile TV]. Reuters (February 6, 2008). Retrieved on June 1, 2009</ref>
Solaris was intended to first use the Eutelsat [[W series (satellites)|W2A]] satellite at 10° east, which contains an S-band payload, and was scheduled for launch in early 2009. However, following the successful launch on April 3, 2009, the S-band payload was found to show "an anomaly" which has put in doubt the payload's capability to provide mobile satellite services for Solaris.<ref>{{cite press release|publisher=Solaris Mobile |date=May 14, 2009 |url= http://www.solarismobile.com/assets/downloads/Statement%20re%20Solaris%20Mobile%20S-band%20capacity_en.pdf |title= Statement re Solaris Mobile S-band capacity}} [http://www.ses.com/4233325/news/2009/4470775 SES ''Statement on Solaris Mobile S-band capacity'']</ref>
Further testing of the satellite was undertaken to establish its future in the Solaris programme. Investigation of S-band payload has confirmed significant non-compliance from its original specifications. On 1 July 2009, Solaris Mobile filed an insurance claim. The technical findings indicate that the company should be able to offer some, but not all of the services it was planning to offer.<ref>{{cite press release|publisher=Solaris Mobile |date=July 1, 2009 |url=http://www.solarismobile.com/assets/downloads/SolarisMobileFilesInsuranceClaim.pdf |title=Solaris Mobile Files Insurance Claim}} [http://www.ses.com/4233325/news/2009/4468872 SES statement: ''Solaris Mobile Files Insurance Claim'']</ref>
==Regulatory== On June 30, 2008 the [[European Parliament]] and the [[European Council|Council]] adopted the European’s Decision to establish a single selection and authorisation process to ensure a coordinated introduction of mobile satellite services (MSS) in Europe. The selection process was launched in August 2008 and attracted four applications by prospective operators ([[ICO Global Communications|ICO]], [[Inmarsat]], Solaris Mobile, [[TerreStar]]).<ref>{{cite press release|publisher=European Commission |date=August 22, 2007 |url=http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=IP/07/1243 |title=Commission boost for mobile satellite services paves the way for EU-wide high speed data communications}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release|publisher=European Commission |date=August 7, 2008 |url=http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=IP/08/1250 |title=New Satellites for Europe: Commission starts selection procedure for operators of pan-European mobile satellite services}}</ref>
In May 2009, the [[European Commission]] selected two operators, [[Inmarsat]] Ventures and Solaris Mobile, giving these operators "the right to use the specific radio frequencies identified in the Commission's decision and the right to operate their respective mobile satellite systems". EU Member States now have to ensure that the two operators have the right to use the specific radio frequencies identified in the Commission's decision and the right to operate their respective mobile satellite systems for 18 years from the selection decision. The operators are compelled to start operations within 24 months from the selection decision.<ref name="ec press"/><ref>{{cite press release|publisher=European Commission |date=May 14, 2009 |url=http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=MEMO/09/237 |title=Mobile Satellite Services in Europe: Frequently Asked Questions}}</ref><ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/rbssTechMediaTelecomNews/idUSBRQ00733920090514 ''Inmarsat and Solaris win EU spectrum rights''] Reuters (May 14, 2009). Retrieved July 27, 2009</ref><ref>[http://ec.europa.eu/information_society/policy/ecomm/current/pan_european/index_en.htm ''Pan-European numbers and services'']. European Commission ''Information Society'' website. Retrieved July 27, 2009</ref>
Although the EU’s decision was announced days after the apparent failure of the payload intended to serve Solaris, the company remains confident of "its ability to meet the commitments made under the European Commission selection process".<ref>{{cite press release|publisher=Solaris Mobile |date=May 14, 2009 |url=http://www.solarismobile.com/assets/downloads/Solaris%20Mobile%20welcomes%20the%20European%20Commission%20selection%20decision%20for%20the%20S-%20Band%20process_en.pdf |title=Solaris Mobile welcomes the European Commission selection decision for the S-band process}}</ref>
In May 2010, Solaris Mobile announced that following the granting of spectrum by the European Commission, the company had been actively pursuing licenses from European member states and it had just been granted 18-year licences to operate Mobile Satellite Services in France, Sweden and Germany, to add to existing licenses for Finland, Luxembourg, Italy, and Slovenia.<ref>{{cite press release|publisher=Solaris Mobile|date=May 11, 2010|url= http://www.solarismobile.com/media-center/press-releases/european-license-progress |title= European License Progress}}</ref>

'''Equivalent input''' (also '''input-referred''' or '''input-related'''), is a method of referring to the signal or noise level at the output of a system as if it were an input to the same system. This is accomplished by removing all signal changes (e.g. [[amplifier]] [[Gain (electronics)|gain]], [[transducer]] [[sensitivity (electronics)|sensitivity]], etc.) to get the units to match the input.<ref name="IEC61000-4-3">[http://webstore.iec.ch/Webstore/webstore.nsf/Artnum_PK/39224 IEC61000-4-3], Electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) - Part 4-3: Testing and measurement techniques - Radiated, radio-frequency, electromagnetic field immunity test</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aes.org/par/e/#ein|title=AES Pro Audio Reference - EIN|last=|first=|date=|website=www.aes.org|language=en|access-date=2018-02-25}}</ref>
== Examples == === Equivalent Input Noise (EIN) === A [[microphone]] converts [[acoustical]] [[energy]] to [[electrical]] energy. Microphones have some level of electrical [[noise]] at their output. This noise may have contributions from random [[diaphragm (acoustics)|diaphragm]] movement, [[thermal noise]], or a dozen other sources, but those can all be thought of as an imaginary acoustic noise source injecting sound into the (now noiseless) microphone. The units on this noise are no longer [[volts]], but units of sound pressure ([[pascals]] or [[dBSPL]]), which can be directly compared to the desired sound pressure inputs.
=== Input-Related Interference Level (IRIL) === A device which uses a [[microphone]] may be susceptible to [[electromagnetic interference]] which causes [[sonic artifact]]s. The problem is not in the microphone, but the interference level can be ''related'' back to the input to compare to the level of typical inputs to see how [[Hearing|audible]] the artifact is.

|} |} Worldwide '''growth of photovoltaics''' has been an [[Exponential growth|exponential curve]] between 1992–2017. During this period of time, [[photovoltaics]] (PV), also known as solar PV, evolved from a niche market of small scale applications to a mainstream electricity source. When [[solar PV system]]s were first recognized as a promising [[renewable energy]] technology, programs, such as [[feed-in tariff]]s, were implemented by a number of governments in order to provide economic incentives for investments. For several years, growth was mainly driven by Japan and pioneering European countries. As a consequence, cost of solar declined significantly due to [[experience curve effects]] like improvements in technology and [[economies of scale]]. Experience curves describe that the price of a thing decreases with the sum-total ever produced. PV growth increased even more rapidly when production of [[solar cell]]s and [[Solar panel|modules]] started to ramp up in the USA with their [[Million Solar Roofs]] project, and when renewables were added to China's 2011 five-year-plan for energy production.{{cite web |last1=Lacey |first1=Stephen |title=How China dominates solar power |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2011/sep/12/how-china-dominates-solar-power |work=Guardian Environment Network |accessdate=29 June 2014 |date=12 September 2011}} Since then, deployment of photovoltaics has gained momentum on a worldwide scale, particularly in Asia but also in North America and other regions, where solar PV by 2015–17 was increasingly competing with [[conventional energy]] sources as [[grid parity]] has already been reached in about 30 countries.{{cite web |url=https://www.db.com/cr/en/docs/solar_report_full_length.pdf |title=Crossing the Chasm |publisher=Deutsche Bank Markets Research |date=27 February 2015 |format=PDF |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6XSrEw1QL |archivedate=1 April 2015 |deadurl=no}}{{rp|9}} Projections for photovoltaic growth are difficult and burdened with many uncertainties. Official agencies, such as the [[International Energy Agency]] consistently increased their estimates over the years, but still fell short of actual deployment.{{cite news |url=https://cleantechnica.com/2017/04/19/trump-admin-outlines-global-solar-plan-10-terawatts-2030/ |title=Trump Admin. Outlines Global Solar Plan: 10 Terawatts By 2030 |accessdate=19 April 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://energywatchgroup.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/EWG_WEO-Study_2015.pdf |title=The projections for the future and quality in the past of the World Energy Outlook for solar PV and other renewable energy technologies |format=PDF |publisher=Energywatchgroup |date=September 2015}}{{cite web |last1=Osmundsen |first1=Terje |title=How the IEA exaggerates the costs and underestimates the growth of solar power |url=http://www.energypost.eu/iea-exaggerates-costs-underestimates-growth-solar-power/ |website=Energy Post |accessdate=30 October 2014 |date=4 March 2014 |archivedate=30 October 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Tho10h3T |deadurl=no}}{{cite web |last1=Whitmore |first1=Adam |title=Why Have IEA Renewables Growth Projections Been So Much Lower Than the Out-Turn? |url=http://theenergycollective.com/onclimatechangepolicy/286586/why-have-iea-s-projections-renewables-growth-been-so-much-lower-out-tur |website=The Energy Collective |accessdate=30 October 2014 |date=14 October 2013 |archivedate=30 October 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ThoCrwDs |deadurl=no}} Historically, the [[Solar power in the United States|United States]] was the leader of installed photovoltaics for many years, and its total [[Nameplate capacity|capacity]] amounted to 77 [[megawatt]]s in 1996—more than any other country in the world at the time. Then, [[Solar power in Japan|Japan]] was the world's leader of produced solar electricity until 2005, when [[Solar power in Germany|Germany]] took the lead and by 2016 had a capacity of over 40 gigawatts. However, in 2015, China became world's largest producer of photovoltaic power,https://www.reuters.com/article/china-solar-idUSL3N15533Uhttp://www.businessgreen.com/bg/news/2442764/chinese-solar-capacity-outshone-germanys-in-2015http://cleantechnica.com/2016/01/22/china-overtakes-germany-become-worlds-leading-solar-pv-country/ and in 2017 became the first country to surpass the 100 GW of cumulative installed PV capacity.{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-05-16/china-targets-70-gigawatts-of-solar-power-to-cut-coal-reliance.html |title=China Targets 70 Gigawatts of Solar Power to Cut Coal Reliance |website=[[Bloomberg News]] |date=16 May 2014 |accessdate=16 May 2014}}{{cite web |url=https://cleantechnica.com/2015/03/19/chinas-national-energy-administration-17-8-gw-new-solar-pv-2015/ |title=China’s National Energy Administration: 17.8 GW Of New Solar PV In 2015 (~20% Increase) |work=CleanTechnica |date=19 March 2015}} China is expected to be the leader in installed PV capacity, and along with India and US, it is forecasted to be the largest market for solar PV installations in the coming decade. By the end of 2017, cumulative photovoltaic capacity reached about 401 [[gigawatt]]s (GW), estimated to be sufficient to supply 2.1% of global electricity demand.http://www.bp.com/en/global/corporate/energy-economics/statistical-review-of-world-energy/renewable-energy/solar-energy.html Solar contributed 8%, 7.4% and 7.1% to the respective annual domestic consumption in [[Solar power in Italy|Italy]], [[Solar power in Greece|Greece]] and Germany. The European Photovoltaic Industry Association, a solar industry trade group, claims installed worldwide capacity will more than double or even triple to more than 500 GW between 2016 and 2020; by 2050, it claims [[solar power]] will become the world's largest source of electricity. Such an achievement would require PV capacity to grow to 4,600 GW, of which more than half was forecast to be deployed in China and [[Solar power in India|India]]. == Current status == [[Nameplate capacity]] denotes the peak power output of power stations in unit watt [[Unit prefix|prefixed]] as convenient, to e.g. [[kilowatt]] (kW), [[megawatt]] (MW) and [[gigawatt]] (GW). Because power output for variable renewable sources is unpredictable, however, using nameplate capacity as a metric significantly overstates a source's average generation. Thus, capacity is typically multiplied by a suitable [[capacity factor]], which takes into account varying conditions - weather, nighttime, latitude, maintenance, etc. to give energy planners an idea of a source's value to the public. In addition, depending on context, the stated peak power may be prior to a subsequent conversion to [[alternating current]], e.g. for a single photovoltaic panel, or include this conversion and its loss for a grid connected [[photovoltaic power station]].{{rp|15}}{{rp|10}} Worldwide, the average solar PV capacity factor is 11%. [[Wind power]] has different characteristics, e.g. a higher [[capacity factor]] and about four times the 2015 electricity production of solar power. Compared with wind power, photovoltaic power production correlates well with power consumption for air-conditioning in warm countries. {{Asof|2017}} a handful of utilities have started combining PV installations with battery banks, thus obtaining several hours of [[dispatchable generation]] to help mitigate problems associated with the [[duck curve]] after sunset.{{cite news |url= http://www.treehugger.com/energy-policy/tesla-kills-duck-big-batteries.html |work= [[TreeHugger]] |title= Tesla kills the duck with big batteries |first= Lloyd |last= Alter |date= 2017-01-31 |accessdate= 2017-03-16}}{{cite news|url= https://www.cnbc.com/2017/03/08/tesla-battery-packs-power-the-hawaiian-island-of-kauai-after-dark.html |website= [[CNBC|cnbc.com]] |title= Tesla battery packs power the Hawaiian island of Kauai after dark |first= Phil |last= LeBeau |date= 2017-03-08 |accessdate= 2017-03-16}} For a complete history of deployment over the last two decades, also see section ''[[#History of deployment|History of deployment]]''. === Worldwide === In 2017, photovoltaic capacity increased by 95 GW, with a 34% growth year-on-year of new installations. Cumulative installed capacity exceeded 401 GW by the end of the year, sufficient to supply 2.1 percent of the world's total [[electricity consumption]].{{cite web |url=http://www.iea-pvps.org/fileadmin/dam/public/report/statistics/IEA-PVPS_-_A_Snapshot_of_Global_PV_-_1992-2016__1_.pdf|title=Snapshot of Global Photovoltaic Markets 2017|date=19 April 2017 |accessdate=11 July 2017 |format=PDF |work=report |publisher=International Energy Agency}} {{Pie chart | thumb = right | caption =Cumulative PV capacity by region as of the end of 2017. | other = | label1 =Europe | value1 =28 | color1 =forestgreen | label2 =Asia | value2 =50 | color2 =#de2821 | label3 =Americas | value3 =19 | color3 =#2E5CB8 | label4 =MEA | value4 =2.0 | color4 =yellow | label5 =Rest of the World | value5 =1 | color5 =#666666 }} === Regions === As of 2018, Asia was the fastest growing region, with almost 75% of global installations. China alone accounted for more than half of worldwide deployment in 2017. In terms of cumulative capacity, Asia was the most developed region with more than half of the global total of 401 GW in 2017. Europe continued to decline as a percentage of the global PV market. In 2017, Europe represented 28% of global capacity, the Americas 19% and Middle East 2%. Solar PV covered 3.5% and 7% of European electricity demand and [[peak electricity demand]], respectively in 2014.{{rp|6}} === Countries === {{main article|Solar power by country}} {{Pie chart | thumb = right | caption =Added PV capacity by country in 2017 (by percent of world total, clustered by region) | other = | label1 =[[Solar power in China|China]] | value1 =55.8 | color1 =#de2821 | label2 =[[Solar power in Japan|Japan]] | value2 =7.4 | color2 =#800000 | label3 =[[Solar power in South Korea|South Korea]] | value3 =1.3 | color3 =pink | label4 =[[Solar power in India|India]] | value4 =9.6 | color4 =#FFF380 | label5 =[[Solar power in Australia|Australia]] | value5 =1.3 | color5 =#CC6600 | label6 =[[Solar power in the United States|United States]] | value6 =11.2 | color6 =#3366CC | label7 =[[Solar power in Brazil|Brazil]] | value7 =0.9 | color7 =#33CCFF | label8 =[[Solar power in Turkey|Turkey]] | value8 =2.7 | color8 =#850AFF | label9 =[[Solar power in Germany|Germany]] | value9 =1.9 | color9 =#008000 | label10 =[[Solar power in the United Kingdom|United Kingdom]] | value10 =0.9 | color10 = #54C571 | label11 =[[Solar power in France|France]] | value11 =0.9 | color11 =#808000 | label12 =[[Solar power in the Netherlands|Netherlands]] | value12 =0.9 | color12 =#00FF00 | label13 =[[Solar power in the European Union|Rest of Europe]] | value13 =1.5 | color13 =forestgreen | label14 =Rest of the World | value14 =3.7 | color14 =#666666 }} Worldwide growth of photovoltaics is extremely dynamic and varies strongly by country. The top installers of 2017 were China, the United States, and India.[https://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/iea-global-installed-pv-capacity-leaps-to-303-gw IEA: Global Installed PV Capacity Leaps to 303 Gigawatts], greentechmedia, Eric Wesoff, April 27, 2017 There are more than 24 countries around the world with a cumulative PV capacity of more than one gigawatt. The Philippines, Turkey, Israel, and Brazil all crossed the one gigawatt total installations mark in 2017 which Austria, Chile, and South Africa did in 2016. The available solar PV capacity in Honduras is sufficient to supply 12.5% of the nation's electrical power while [[#Italy|Italy]], Germany and [[#Greece|Greece]] can produce between 7% and 8% of their respective domestic electricity consumption. First it was the United States, then Japan, followed by Germany, and currently China. === United States (1954–1996) === The [[Solar power in the United States|United States]], where modern solar PV was invented, led installed capacity for many years. Based on preceding work by Swedish and German engineers, the American engineer [[Russell Ohl]] at [[Bell Labs]] patented the first modern solar cell in 1946.[http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO1&Sect2=HITOFF&d=PALL&p=1&u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsrchnum.htm&r=1&f=G&l=50&s1=2402662.PN.&OS=PN/2402662&RS=PN/2402662 United States Patent and Trademark Office – Database]{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9CcDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA41 |title=Magic Plates, Tap Sun For Power|publisher=Popular Science |date=June 1931|accessdate=2 August 2013}} It was also there at Bell Labs where the first practical [[Crystalline silicon|c-silicon]] cell was developed in 1954.{{cite web|url=http://www.aps.org/publications/apsnews/200904/physicshistory.cfm|title=Bell Labs Demonstrates the First Practical Silicon Solar Cell|work=aps.org}}{{cite web|url=http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/journal/jap/25/5/10.1063/1.1721711|title=Journal of Applied Physics — A New Silicon p–n Junction Photocell for Converting Solar Radiation into Electrical Power|author=D. M. Chapin-C. S. Fuller-G. L. Pearson|work=aip.org}} [[Hoffman Electronics]], the leading manufacturer of silicon solar cells in the 1950s and 1960s, improved on the cell's efficiency, produced solar radios, and equipped [[Vanguard I]], the first [[Solar panels on spacecraft|solar powered satellite]] launched into orbit in 1958. In 1977 US-President [[Jimmy Carter]] installed [[solar hot water panel]]s on the White House promoting [[solar energy]]{{cite web |author=Biello David |title=Where Did the Carter White House's Solar Panels Go? |url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/carter-white-house-solar-panel-array/ |website=Scientific American |accessdate=31 July 2014 |date=6 August 2010}} and the [[National Renewable Energy Laboratory]], originally named ''Solar Energy Research Institute'' was established at Golden, Colorado. In the 1980s and early 1990s, most photovoltaic modules were used in [[stand-alone power system]]s or powered consumer products such as [[Solar-powered watch|watches]], [[Solar-powered calculator|calculators]] and toys, but from around 1995, industry efforts have focused increasingly on developing grid-connected [[rooftop PV system]]s and [[Photovoltaic power station|power stations]]. By 1996, solar PV capacity in the US amounted to 77 megawatts–more than any other country in the world at the time. Then, Japan moved ahead. === Japan (1997–2004) === [[Solar power in Japan|Japan]] took the lead as the world's largest producer of PV electricity, after the city of Kobe was hit by the [[Great Hanshin earthquake]] in 1995. Kobe experienced severe power outages in the aftermath of the earthquake, and [[PV systems]] were then considered as a temporary supplier of power during such events, as the disruption of the [[electric grid]] paralyzed the entire infrastructure, including gas stations that depended on electricity to pump gasoline. Moreover, in December of that same year, an accident occurred at the multibillion-dollar experimental [[Monju Nuclear Power Plant]]. A sodium leak caused a major fire and forced a shutdown (classified as [[International Nuclear Event Scale|INES]] 1). There was massive public outrage when it was revealed that the semigovernmental agency in charge of Monju had tried to cover up the extent of the accident and resulting damage.{{cite news| title=REACTOR ACCIDENT IN JAPAN IMPERILS ENERGY PROGRAM| first=Andrew | last=Pollack | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/24/world/reactor-accident-in-japan-imperils-energy-program.html| work=New York Times| date=24 February 1996}}wise-paris.org [http://www.wise-paris.org/index.html?/english/ournewsletter/2/page7.html&/english/frame/menu.html&/english/frame/band.html Sodium Leak and Fire at Monju] Japan remained world leader in photovoltaics until 2004, when its capacity amounted to 1,132 megawatts. Then, focus on PV deployment shifted to Europe. === Germany (2005–2014) === In 2005, [[Solar power in Germany|Germany]] took the lead from Japan. With the introduction of the [[German Renewable Energy Act|Renewable Energy Act]] in 2000, [[feed-in tariffs]] were adopted as a policy mechanism. This policy established that renewables have priority on the grid, and that a fixed price must be paid for the produced electricity over a 20-year period, providing a guaranteed return on investment irrespective of actual market prices. As a consequence, a high level of investment security lead to a soaring number of new photovoltaic installations that peaked in 2011, while investment costs in renewable technologies were brought down considerably. In 2016 Germany's installed PV capacity was over the 40 GW mark. === China (2015–present) === China surpassed Germany's capacity by the end of 2015, becoming the world's largest producer of photovoltaic power.{{cite web |url= http://cleantechnica.com/2016/01/22/china-overtakes-germany-become-worlds-leading-solar-pv-country/|title= China Overtakes Germany To Become World’s Leading Solar PV Country|first= Joshua|last=S Hill |date= January 22, 2016|accessdate= August 16, 2016|work= Clean Technica}} [[Solar power in China|China]]'s rapid PV growth continued in 2016 – with 34.2 GW of solar photovoltaics installed.{{Cite web|url=http://www.solarserver.com/solar-magazine/solar-news/current/2017/kw03/nea-china-added-3424-gw-of-solar-pv-capacity-in-2016.html|title=NEA: China added 34.24 GW of solar PV capacity in 2016|last=|first=|date=|website=www.solarserver.com|publisher=|language=en|access-date=2017-01-22}} The [https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-renewables-tariffs-idUSKBN0U703Y20151224 quickly lowering feed in tariff rates] at the end of 2015 motivated many developers to secure tariff rates before mid-year 2016 – as they were anticipating further cuts ([http://www.renewableenergyworld.com/articles/2016/10/china-to-lower-feed-in-tariff-cut-subsidies-for-solar-pv-systems.html correctly so]). During the course of the year, China announced its goal of installing 100 GW during the next [[Five-year plans of China|Chinese Five Year Economic Plan]] (2016–2020). China expected to spend ¥1 trillion ($145B) on solar construction{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-energy-renewables-idUSKBN14P06P|title=China to plow $361 billion into renewable fuel by 2020|date=2017-01-05|newspaper=Reuters|access-date=2017-01-22}} during that period. Much of China's PV capacity was built in the relatively less populated west of the country whereas the main centres of power consumption were in the east (such as Shanghai and Beijing).{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-40341833|title=Future Energy: China leads world in solar power production|last=Baraniuk|first=Chris|date=2017-06-22|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-06-27|language=en-GB}} Due to lack of adequate power transmission lines to carry the power from the solar power plants, China had to curtail its PV generated power.{{Cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/china/policies-politics/article/2088865/china-wasted-enough-renewable-energy-power-beijing|title=China wasted enough renewable energy to power Beijing for an entire year, says Greenpeace|language=en|accessdate=19 April 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/business/article/2088905/china-erect-fewer-farms-generate-less-solar-power-2017|title=China to erect fewer farms, generate less solar power in 2017|language=en|accessdate=19 April 2017}} == History of market development == === Prices and costs (1977–present) === {{multiple image |direction = vertical |align = right |width1= 220 |width2= 220 |image1=Swansons-law.svg |image2=Price history of silicon PV cells since 1977.svg |caption1=[[Swanson's law]] – the PV learning curve |caption2=Price decline of [[crystalline silicon|c-Si]] [[solar cell]]s }} {| class="wikitable floatleft" style="font-size: 0.9em; margin-right: 12px; margin-top: 12px" |- ! In 2013, Suntech filed for bankruptcy in China. {{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/21/business/energy-environment/chinese-solar-companys-operating-unit-declares-bankruptcy.html?pagewanted=all |title=Chinese Subsidiary of Suntech Power Declares Bankruptcy |date=20 March 2013 |work=New York Times }} {{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-04-29/suntech-seeks-new-cash-after-china-bankruptcy-liquidator-says.html |title=Suntech Seeks New Cash After China Bankruptcy, Liquidator Says |date= 29 April 2014 |work=Bloomberg News }} === Silicon shortage (2005–2008) === [[File:Polysilicon prices history since 2004.svg|thumb|[[Polysilicon]] prices since 2004. As of October 2018, the [[Average selling price|ASP]] for polysilicon stands at $9.802/kg]] In the early 2000s, prices for [[polysilicon]], the raw material for conventional solar cells, were as low as $30 per kilogram and silicon manufacturers had no incentive to expand production. However, there was a severe silicon shortage in 2005, when governmental programmes caused a 75% increase in the deployment of solar PV in Europe. In addition, the demand for silicon from semiconductor manufacturers was growing. Since the amount of silicon needed for semiconductors makes up a much smaller portion of production costs, semiconductor manufacturers were able to outbid solar companies for the available silicon in the market.Wired.com [http://archive.wired.com/science/planetearth/news/2005/03/67013 Silicon Shortage Stalls Solar] 28 March 2005 Initially, the incumbent polysilicon producers were slow to respond to rising demand for solar applications, because of their painful experience with over-investment in the past. Silicon prices sharply rose to about $80 per kilogram, and reached as much as $400/kg for long-term contracts and spot prices. In 2007, the constraints on silicon became so severe that the solar industry was forced to idle about a quarter of its cell and module manufacturing capacity—an estimated 777 MW of the then available production capacity. The shortage also provided silicon specialists with both the cash and an incentive to develop new technologies and several new producers entered the market. Early responses from the solar industry focused on improvements in the recycling of silicon. When this potential was exhausted, companies have been taking a harder look at alternatives to the conventional [[Siemens process]]. {{cite web |title=Solar State of the Market Q3 2008 – Rise of Upgraded Metallurgical Silicon |url=http://www.solarweb.net/forosolar/attachments/aspectos-economicos-legales-administrativos/937d1241049999-verdadero-coste-la-energia-solar-espana-lux_research_rise_of_upgraded_metallurgical_silicon.pdf |website=SolarWeb |publisher= Lux Research Inc. |page=1 |accessdate=12 October 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6TFljtiw4 |archivedate=12 October 2014 |deadurl=yes }} As it takes about three years to build a new polysilicon plant, the shortage continued until 2008. Prices for conventional solar cells remained constant or even rose slightly during the period of silicon shortage from 2005 to 2008. This is notably seen as a "shoulder" that sticks out in the [[commons:File:Swansons-law.png|Swanson's PV-learning curve]] and it was feared that a prolonged shortage could delay solar power becoming competitive with conventional energy prices without subsidies. In the meantime the solar industry lowered the number of grams-per-watt by reducing wafer thickness and kerf loss, increasing yields in each manufacturing step, reducing module loss, and raising panel efficiency. Finally, the ramp up of polysilicon production alleviated worldwide markets from the scarcity of silicon in 2009 and subsequently lead to an overcapacity with sharply declining prices in the photovoltaic industry for the following years. === Solar overcapacity (2009–2013) === {{thumb | width = 235 |pos=bottom |content=

Prices for silicon stabilized around $20 per kilogram and the booming solar PV market helped to reduce the enormous global overcapacity from 2009 onwards. However, overcapacity in the PV industry continued to persist. In 2013, global record deployment of 38 GW (updated EPIA figure) was still much lower than China's annual production capacity of approximately 60 GW. Continued overcapacity was further reduced by significantly lowering [[solar module]] prices and, as a consequence, many manufacturers could no longer cover costs or remain competitive. As worldwide growth of PV deployment continued, the gap between overcapacity and global demand was expected in 2014 to close in the next few years. {{cite web |title=Annual Report 2013/2014 |url=http://www.ise.fraunhofer.de/en/publications/veroeffentlichungen-pdf-dateien-en/infomaterial/annual-reports/fraunhofer-ise-annual-report-2013-14.pdf |website=ISE.Fraunhofer.de |publisher=Fraunhofer Institute for Solar Energy Systems-ISE |accessdate=5 November 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6TrDlHLYv |archivedate=5 November 2014 |page=1 |format=PDF |date=2014 |deadurl=no }} IEA-PVPS published in 2014 historical data for the worldwide utilization of solar PV module production capacity that showed a slow return to normalization in manufacture in the years leading up to 2014. The utilization rate is the ratio of production capacities versus actual production output for a given year. A low of 49% was reached in 2007 and reflected the peak of the silicon shortage that idled a significant share of the module production capacity. |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6YBbgC1Xf |archivedate=30 April 2015 }} All this has caused much controversy between proponents and opponents and was subject of debate. == History of deployment == Deployment figures on a global, regional and nationwide scale are well documented since the early 1990s. While worldwide photovoltaic capacity grew continuously, deployment figures by country were much more dynamic, as they depended strongly on national policies. A number of organizations release comprehensive reports on PV deployment on a yearly basis. They include annual and cumulative deployed PV [[nameplate capacity|capacity]], typically given in [[watt-peak]], a break-down by markets, as well as in-depth analysis and forecasts about future trends. {{Timeline of the largest PV power stations in the world}} === Worldwide annual deployment === {{Image frame |width = 220 |align=right |pos=bottom |content=

}} {{clear left}} === Worldwide cumulative === [[File:PV cume semi log chart 2014 estimate.svg|thumb|Worldwide cumulative PV capacity on a semi log chart since 1992]] Worldwide growth of solar PV capacity was an exponential curve between 1992 and 2017. Tables below show global cumulative nominal capacity by the end of each year in [[megawatts]], and the year-to-year increase in percent. In 2014, global capacity was expected to grow by 33 percent from 139 to 185 GW. This corresponded to an exponential growth rate of 29 percent or about 2.4 years for current worldwide PV capacity to [[Doubling time|double]]. Exponential growth rate: P(t) = P0ert, where ''P0'' is 139 GW, growth-rate ''r'' 0.29 (results in [[doubling time]] ''t'' of 2.4 years). {{Unreferenced|date=June 2010}} <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Epson ET-10 handheldtv84.jpg|300px|thumbnail|[[Epson]] model ET-10 (1984).]] --> A '''handheld television''' is a [[portable device]] for watching [[television]] that usually uses a [[thin-film transistor|TFT]] [[LCD]] or [[OLED]] [[color graphics|color]] display. Many of these devices resemble [[handheld]] [[transistor radio]]s.
==History== [[File:Sony watchman fd210.jpg|thumb|Sony Watchman]] In the 1970s and early 1980s, [[Panasonic]] and [[Sinclair Research]] released the first TVs which were small enough to fit in a large pocket; called the Panasonic IC TV MODEL TR-001 and [[MTV-1]]. Since [[LCD]] technology was not yet mature at the time, the TV used a minuscule [[cathode ray tube|CRT]] which set the record for being the smallest CRT on a commercially marketed product.
Later in 1982, [[Sony]] released the first model of the [[Sony Watchman|Watchman]], a [[pun]] on [[Walkman]]. It had grayscale video at first. Several years later, a color model with an [[Active-matrix liquid crystal display|active-matrix]] LCD was released. Some [[smartphone]]s integrate a television receiver, although Internet broadband video is far more common.
Since the switch-over to digital broadcasting, handheld TVs have reduced in size and improved in quality.{{dubious|reason=See talk page|date=August 2018}}{{cn|date=August 2018}} The major current manufacturers of [[DVB-T]] standard (common throughout Europe) handheld TVs are August International, ODYS and Xoro.
==Hardware== [[File:Pocket Television CRT.svg|thumb|Elements of a pocket television CRT: (1) Recessed Screen, (2) Electron Beam, (3) Electron Gun]] These devices often have stereo 1⁄8 inch (3.5 mm) [[phono plug]]s for [[composite video]]-analog mono audio relay to serve them as [[composite monitor]]s; also, some models have mono 3.5 mm jacks for the broadcast signal that is usually relayed via [[F connector]] or [[Belling-Lee connector]] on standard television models.
Some include [[HDMI]], [[USB]] and [[Secure Digital|SD]] ports.
Screen sizes vary from {{convert|1.3|to|5|in}}. Some handheld televisions also double as portable [[DVD player]]s and [[digital video recorder|USB personal video recorders]].
==Size== '''Portable televisions''' cannot fit in a pocket, but often run on batteries and include a [[cigarette lighter receptacle]] plug.
'''Pocket televisions''' fit in a pocket.
'''Wearable televisions''' sometimes are made in the form of a [[wristwatch]].
==Notable brands and models== * [[August International]] - DA100C * [[ODYS]] - LIVE * [[Xoro]] - HSD7790 * [[RCA]] - DPTM70R
==See also== *[[Handheld electronics]]
==External links== *[http://www.guenthoer.de/e-history.htm History of the pocket TV] * Vintage Micro Television http://www.visions4.net/journal/time-line/
